chapterMeaning: The Yoga of Knowledge and Wisdom
sanskrit:
भूमिरापोऽनलो वायुः खं मनो बुद्धिरेव च ।
अहङ्कार इतीयं मे भिन्ना प्रकृतिरष्टधा ॥४॥
transliteration:
bhūmir āpo 'nalo vāyuḥ khaṁ mano buddhir eva ca |
ahaṅkāra itīyaṁ me bhinnā prakṛtir aṣṭadhā ||4||
translation: Earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect, and ego—these constitute My eightfold divided material nature (Prakriti).
commentary:
In this verse, Krishna begins to explain His divine nature by describing His lower material nature (apara prakriti). He enumerates eight fundamental elements that constitute the material world and the subtle aspects of human consciousness. The first five—earth, water, fire, air, and ether—represent the gross physical elements (pancha mahabhutas) that form the physical universe. The remaining three—mind (manas), intellect (buddhi), and ego (ahamkara)—constitute the subtle psychological instruments through which consciousness operates in the material realm.

This classification is significant because it establishes the foundation for understanding Krishna's dual nature. While these eight elements constitute His lower, material nature, Krishna will soon reveal in the following verses that He possesses a higher, spiritual nature (para prakriti) which is the life force that animates all beings. This verse is crucial in Vedantic philosophy as it provides a systematic analysis of material existence, showing that even the mind and intellect, though subtle, are still part of material nature and distinct from the pure consciousness of the Self. Understanding this distinction is essential for spiritual progress, as it helps the seeker discriminate between the eternal Self and the temporary modifications of material nature.
speaker: Krishna
